definitions.definition: To put a mark on (something); to make (something) recognizable by a mark; to label or write on (something).
examples: to mark a box or bale of merchandise
to mark clothing with one's name

definitions.definition: To leave a mark (often an undesirable or unwanted one) on (something).
examples: See where this pencil has marked the paper.
The floor was marked with wine and blood.

definitions.definition: ( figurative ) To have a long-lasting negative impact on (someone or something).
To create an indication of (a location).
examples: She folded over the corner of the page to mark where she left off reading.
Some animals mark their territory by urinating.

definitions.definition: To be an indication of (something); to show where (something) is located.
examples: This monument marks the spot where Wolfe died.
A bell marked the end of visiting hours.

definitions.definition: To indicate (something) in writing or by other symbols.
examples: Prices are marked on individual items.
In her Bible, the words of Christ were marked in red.

definitions.definition: To create (a mark) on a surface.
To celebrate or acknowledge (an event ) through an action of some kind.
examples: The national holiday is marked by fireworks.

definitions.definition: ( of things ) To identify (someone as a particular type of person or as having a particular role).
examples: His courage and energy marked him as a leader.

definitions.definition: ( of people ) To assign (someone) to a particular category or class.
( of people ) To choose or intend (someone) for a particular end or purpose.
To be a point in time or space at which something takes place; to accompany or be accompanied by (an event, action, etc.); to coincide with.
examples: The creek marks the boundary between the two farms.
That summer marked the beginning of her obsession with cycling.

definitions.definition: To be typical or characteristic of (something).
To distinguish (one person or thing from another).
( dated except in the phrase " mark my words " ) To focus one's attention on (something or someone); to pay attention to, to take note of.
examples: Mark my words: that boy’s up to no good.

definitions.definition: ( dated ) To become aware of (something) through the physical senses .
To hold (someone) in one's line of sight .
( Canada , UK ) To indicate the correctness of and give a score to (a school assignment , exam answers, etc.).
examples: The teacher had to spend her weekend marking all the tests.

definitions.definition: To record that (someone) has a particular status.
examples: to mark a student absent.

definitions.definition: ( transitive , intransitive ) To keep account of; to enumerate and register; to keep score .
examples: to mark the points in a game of billiards or a card game

definitions.definition: ( sports ) To follow a player not in possession of the ball when defending, to prevent them receiving a pass easily.
( Australian rules football ) To catch the ball directly from a kick of 15 metres or more without having been touched in transit, resulting in a free kick .
( golf ) To put a marker in the place of one's ball.
( singing ) To sing softly, sometimes an octave lower than usual, in order to protect one's voice during a rehearsal .

definitions.definition: Alternative form of march .
examples: Mark time, mark !
Forward, mark !

main_definition: ( imperative , marching ) Alternative form of march .
